item.title: Call Of Duty Passed On Spielberg And Now Heâ€™s Making Gremlins 3
item.content:encoded:
35 years later, Warner Bros has finally announced itâ€™s making a Gremlins 3. The new sequel will be executive-produced by Steven Spielberg, who reportedly was denied a chance to make a Call of Duty movie, so why not help produce a new Gremlins movie instead?

On November 6, Warner Bros. Discovery chief David â€œIâ€™m Bad At My Jobâ€ Zaslav announced during the companyâ€™s third-quarter earnings call that a third Gremlins movie had recently been greenlit and had some big names attached. As mentioned, Spielberg is returning to the franchise to once again be an executive producer and will be producing the sequel through his company, Amblin Entertainment. Meanwhile, the writer behind the OG 1984 Gremlins movie, Chris Columbus, is returning to produce and direct the flick.

As reported by The Hollywood Reporter, Zach Lipovsky and Adam B. Stein are working alongside Columbus to help write the script for Gremlins 3. The duo previously directed this yearâ€™s smash hit horror sequel Final Destinations: Bloodlines.

Warner Bros. has set a November 19, 2027 release date for its new Gremlins sequel. That is 37 years after the last Gremlins movie, making it a true legacy sequel.  Arriving in theaters in 1984, the original Gremlins was a massive box office success. On a budget of just $15 million, the Joe Dante-directed comedy-horror movie about evil little creatures who show up after some rules are broken while taking care of a cute furry mogwai made over $150 million in the US alone.

However, six years later, Gremlins 2, also directed by Dante, only made $41 million, was ravaged by critics and fans and basically killed the franchise. In 2023, WB produced an animated series based on the dormant property and it seems the response to that was strong enough to convince the studio that Gremlins is still a worthwhile franchise. Letâ€™s hope the third movie sticks to puppets and doesnâ€™t go full CG.

And I hope working on Gremlins 3 will help Spielberg get over Activision denying him the chance to make a Call of Duty movie.

item.title: Amazon Clears Out Its Fire TV Soundbar Plus, Now Cheaper Than a Mini Bluetooth Speaker
item.content:encoded:
TVs are getting thinner and thatâ€™s terrific for aesthetic purposes but disastrous for audio quality. Those razor-thin screens donâ€™t have any physical room for decent speakers which means most integrated audio sounds flat, tinny and lifeless.

Amazon definitely noticed this gap in the market and decided to create a solution thatâ€™s largely inspired by premium brands like Bose and Samsung â€“ except the Fire TV soundbar Plus costs two to three times less than comparable models from those manufacturers. Serious Audio Upgrades

The Fire TV soundbar Plus is a fantastic soundbar that houses real home theater technology inside a single sleek unit sitting neatly below your television. This is a 3.1 channel system which means you get three forward-firing speakers combined with a built-in subwoofer for bass in one compact unit. The dedicated center channel takes care of dialogue specifically so that if people are talking in movies or shows, the conversations come across sharp and clear rather than being blurred with background music and effects.

Dolby Atmos support brings 3D audio into the mix with the sensation that sound is moving around and above you rather than just blasting straight ahead. Action scenes feature helicopters flying overhead, atmospheric dramas rain from above, and much more. Support for DTS:X multi-dimensional audio processing for filmmakers and sound designers gives multiple ways to create immersive experiences that this soundbar can actually reproduce.

Special attention is given to the built-in subwoofer as most soundbars in this price range either forgo bass altogether or use a separate wireless subwoofer that requires floor space and its own power outlet. Amazon manages to house the sub directly within the chassis of the soundbar and with it, you gain deep, punchy low frequencies for everything from explosions to music and ambient rumble-all without adding another component to your setup.

Setup couldnâ€™t be any easier since you only have to hook up the included HDMI cable to your TVâ€™s HDMI eARC or ARC port. The same cable carries both audio and control signals, which means the remote from your television can change the soundbarâ€™s volume for you with no unnecessary controller cluttering up your coffee table. Audio sync issues that plague some soundbar setups simply donâ€™t happen here, since the HDMI connection keeps everything perfectly timed.

Itâ€™s compact enough to fit under most TVs without blocking the screen or the remote sensor and has an understated design that lets your entertainment take center stage. For the price, youâ€™re getting tech and performance thatâ€™s regularly between $400-$600 from other established audio brands which makes this one of the single best value propositions in home audio at the moment. And for an all-time low price, itâ€™s an even easier decision.
